@koushik-das For more details about the Host HA definition, and implementation please have a look at the FS: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/CLOUDSTACK/Host+HA

As noted in the FS above, this extends on the design and implementation in an agnostic way from a previous FS: https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/CLOUDSTACK/KVM+HA+with+IPMI+Fencing

The Host-HA framework is agnostic of the mechanism and only enforces policies while the mechanisms can be implemented as plugins. It further imposes or knows any limitation associated with the resource being HA-ed. With this PR, we've presented two Host-HA plugins (a) a HA provider simulator to verify the framework in a _deterministic_ way that's not possible with the status quo, and (b) a HA provider for KVM that uses out-of-band management. This approach clearly and cleanly provides a good policy vs implementation outlook for the developer and for writing good robust tests, than the status quo. We're further also implemented an out-of-band management nested-cloudstack plugin to allow us to test this feature at scale with virtualized KVM-hosts (VMs) with Trillian and other environments.

For current VM-HA VMs are first class resource/objects, while for Host-HA at the framework level the first class resource/objects are agnostic but the implementation is not and is as per host/hypervisor specific plugins (that are free to implement recovery, fencing and other operations). In the KVM specific HA provider we've implemented, it uses oobm based fencing/recoverd/investigation and hosts are first class resources.

For Host-HA to work and execute the recovery and fence operations -- VM HA should not kick-in before host is successfully investigated, recovered, fenced etc. In terms of precedence of execution, Host HA > VM HA i.e. Host-HA operations runs before VM-HA operations. The current VM HA framework does a poor job at reliably fencing a host, at least on KVM based large prod. environments this has shown to cause disk corruptions. Without modifying the current VM HA framework or rewriting it -- this limitation or precedence of execution has been addressed by the KVM HA provider implementation by returning suitable states for VM HA framework to block it from executing before Host-HA completes its operations, but only for suitable hosts i.e where the host-ha provider is configured and enabled and have oobm enable.
Note: for this VM HA _framework_ itself has not been modified, or rewritten in any way.
